htmlEmbed:
Why Bitcoin Is Bad for the EnvironmentCond√© Nast3/22/2021

Elizabeth Kolbert writes about the excessive greenhouse-gas emissions produced by cryptocurrency-mining operations, and reports on old power plants in New York State that are being converted to provide electricity to mining farms in the region.

daily comment, cryptocurrency, mining, bitcoin, climate change, new york state, web, tagsArchivedRead

</script><link rel="dns-prefetch" href="//aax.amazon-adsystem.com"><link rel="preconnect" href="//aax.amazon-adsystem.com" crossorigin><script src="https://c.amazon-adsystem.com/aax2/apstag.js" async></script><script src="/hotzones/esi/the-new-yorker/prebid.min.js" async></script><script src="https://js-sec.indexww.com/ht/p/183973-93942139695505.js" async></script><script></script><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"+++dropcap\n\nMoney, it‚Äôs often said, is a shared fiction. I give you a slip of paper or, more likely these days, a piece of plastic. You hand me eggs or butter or a White Chocolate Mocha Frappuccino, and we both walk away satisfied. With cryptocurrency, the arrangement is more like a shared metafiction, and the instability of the genre is, presumably, part of the thrill. Dogecoin, a cryptocurrency that was created as a spoof, has [risen in value](https://www.reuters.com/technology/dogeday-hashtags-help-meme-based-cryptocurrency-dogecoin-hit-new-high-2021-04-20/) by eight thousand per cent since January, owing to a combination of [GameStop-style](https://www.newyorker.com/news/our-columnists/the-gamestop-saga-is-dangerous-and-all-too-familiar) pumping and boosterish tweets from Elon Musk. On Tuesday, which backers proclaimed DogeDay, the cryptocurrency  was valued at more than fifty billion dollars, which is more than the market cap of Ford. Coinbase, a cryptocurrency exchange, went public last Wednesday; almost immediately, it became worth more than G.M.\n\n+++\n\n+++inset-right\n\n[#externallink: /externallinks/6081cecb3629e8f5c79f662d]\n\n+++\n\nThe mainstreaming of cryptocurrency, as it‚Äôs been called, is obviously a big deal for the world of finance. It‚Äôs also a big deal for the world of, well, the world. This is particularly true in the case of the ur-cryptocurrency, Bitcoin. Like Dogecoin, bitcoin has recently surged in value. In April, 2020, a coin was worth about seven thousand dollars; today, it‚Äôs worth more than fifty-five thousand. (It hit a record high of $64,895.22 on April 14th, but has since fallen off.) As the cost of investing in bitcoin has soared, so, too, has the potential profit in ‚Äúmining‚Äù it. Bitcoin mining is, of course, purely metaphorical, but the results can be every bit as destructive as with the real thing.\n\nAccording to the Cambridge Bitcoin Electricity Consumption Index, bitcoin-mining operations worldwide [now use energy](https://cbeci.org/) at the rate of nearly a hundred and twenty terawatt-hours per year. This is about the annual domestic electricity consumption of the entire nation of Sweden. According to the Web site Digiconomist, a single bitcoin transaction uses [the same amount of power](https://digiconomist.net/bitcoin-energy-consumption) that the average American household consumes in a month, and is responsible for roughly a million times more carbon emissions than a single Visa transaction. At a time when the world desperately needs to cut carbon emissions, does it make sense to be devoting a Sweden‚Äôs worth of electricity to a virtual currency? The answer would seem, pretty clearly, to be no. And, yet, here we are.\n\n+++dropcap\n\nThe Greenidge Generating Station in Dresden, New York, sits on the shores of Seneca Lake, about an hour southeast of Rochester. It was originally built in the nineteen-thirties to run on coal; over the decades, new units were added and older ones shuttered. The power station ceased operations in 2011, and it sat idle until it was purchased by a private-equity firm and converted to run on natural gas. In 2017, under the ownership of Greenidge Generation Holdings, the plant reportedly began operating as a ‚Äúpeaker plant,‚Äù to provide power to the grid during times of high demand. (A spokesperson noted that the plant ‚Äúis permitted to run 24/7.‚Äù) Then, in 2019, it was announced that the plant would  power bitcoin mining.\n\n+++\n\nMining is the process by which bitcoin is both created and accounted for. Instead of being cleared by, say, a bank, bitcoin transactions are recorded by a decentralized network‚Äîa blockchain. Miners compete to register the latest ‚Äúblock‚Äù of transactions by solving cryptographic puzzles. The first one to the solution is rewarded with freshly minted bitcoin. Miners today receive 6.25 bitcoins per block, which, at current values, are worth more than three hundred thousand dollars.\n\nIt‚Äôs unclear exactly who dreamt up bitcoin, so no one knows what this person (or persons) was thinking when the mining protocols were first established. But, as Ari Juels, a computer scientist at Cornell Tech, recently explained to me, the arrangement seems to have been designed with equity in mind. Anyone devoting a processor to the enterprise would have just as much stake in the outcome as anyone else. As is so often the case, though, the ideal was soon subverted.\n\n‚ÄúWhat was quickly discovered is that specialized computing devices‚Äîso-called mining rigs‚Äîare much, much more effective at solving these puzzles,‚Äù Juels said. ‚ÄúAnd, in addition, there are economies of scale in the operation of these mining groups. So the process of mining, which was originally conducted by a loose federation of presumably individual participants with ordinary computing devices, has now become heavily consolidated.‚Äù\n\nBecause rig ‚Äúfarms,‚Äù which are essentially like server farms, consume a lot of energy, bitcoin-mining operations tend to chase cheap electricity. Roughly seventy per cent of bitcoin mining today takes place in China. ([A recent study](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-021-22256-3) found that the associated electricity consumption could ‚Äúpotentially undermine‚Äù China‚Äôs efforts to curb its carbon emissions.) Russia is also a bitcoin-mining center‚Äîthere are big operations in Siberia, where cold temperatures help keep rig farms from overheating‚Äîas is Iran, where electricity is subsidized.\n\nIn the United States, home to about seven per cent of the world‚Äôs bitcoin mining, finding cheap power can be complicated. A few years ago, miners ‚Äú[descended upon](https://www.forbes.com/sites/danieldambrosio/2018/10/31/plattsburgh-turns-back-invasion-of-bitcoin-miners)‚Äù the city of Plattsburgh, New York, about a hundred and fifty miles north of Albany, which gets much of its electricity from hydroelectric dams on the St. Lawrence River. The power is relatively inexpensive, but, once Plattsburgh uses up its allotment, it has to purchase more at higher rates. Bitcoin mining drove up the cost of electricity in the city so dramatically that, in 2018, Plattsburgh enacted a moratorium on new mining operations.\n\nBuying a generating station, as Greenidge Generation Holdings has done, is a way around the problem. Let others pay retail; Greenidge now gets its power ‚Äúbehind the meter.‚Äù The firm [recently announced](https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20210322005353/en/Bitcoin-Miner-Greenidge-Generation-Holdings-Inc.-and-Support.com-Inc.-Nasdaq-SPRT-Announce-Merger-Agreement) that it was going public, via a merger with a Nasdaq-listed company called Support.com, and boasted that it ‚Äúexpects to be the first publicly traded bitcoin mining company with a wholly-owned power plant.‚Äù In the announcement, Greenidge said that it was planning to more than double its bitcoin-mining operations in Dresden by the fall of 2021, and to double them again by the end of 2022. It further declared that it intends to ‚Äúreplicate its vertically integrated mining model at other power sites.‚Äù\n\nTo expand its operations in Dresden, Greenidge will have to burn more and more natural gas, thus producing correspondingly more greenhouse-gas emissions. The firm‚Äôs plans have sparked demonstrations in the Finger Lakes region. On Saturday, a hundred protesters marched to the gates of the plant.\n\n‚ÄúThis is a test case,‚Äù Joseph Campbell, the president of Seneca Lake Guardian, the group that organized the march, [told WRFI](https://www.wrfi.org/2021/04/19/environmentalists-rally-against-greenidge-expansion-state-lawmakers-take-notice/), an Ithaca radio station. Two days later, the local planning board approved Greenidge‚Äôs application to build four new structures at the site, to house more mining rigs. Members of the planning board said that for, legal reasons, they were barred from considering the broader implications of their decision. ‚ÄúWe know that bitcoin is a big waste of energy,‚Äù the chairman of the planning board, David Granzin, [said](https://wskg.org/news/torrey-planning-board-approves-greenidge-bitcoin-mining-plan/). ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre bound by law.‚Äù\n\nWhether this is, in fact, the case is debatable. What‚Äôs beyond debate‚Äîor should be, at least‚Äîis that this is a matter that shouldn‚Äôt be left to a local planning board to decide. There‚Äôs no way for New York, or the U.S. as a whole, to meet its emissions-reductions goals if old generating stations, rather than being closed, are converted into bitcoin-mining operations. Greenidge may become the first mining firm with a ‚Äúwholly-owned power plant,‚Äù but, unless the state or federal government steps in, it won‚Äôt be the last: another cryptocurrency firm, Digihost International, [has already applied](https://fingerlakes1.com/2021/04/19/bitcoin-miners-scout-for-site-in-watkins-glen-canadian-bitcoin-miner-buys-power-plant-near-buffalo/) to New York State‚Äôs Public Service Commission for permission to purchase a natural-gas-burning station near Buffalo. As representatives of Earthjustice and the Sierra Club recently [put it](https://waterfrontonline.files.wordpress.com/2021/04/earthjusticeletterapr6.pdf),  in a letter to officials of New York‚Äôs Department of Environmental Conservation, ‚Äúadditional scrutiny . . . is essential to prevent the floodgates opening for other retiring power plants.‚Äù\n\nAndrew Yang, the former Presidential candidate who‚Äôs now running for mayor of New York City, has said that he wants to turn the city into a cryptocurrency-mining hub. It‚Äôs hard to imagine a worse idea. The city is already looking at spending billions of dollars to protect itself from sea-level rise; increased emissions are pretty much the last thing it needs. Forward-looking politicians should be thinking about ways not to buoy bitcoin mining but to bury it.\n\n","articleSection":"daily comment","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Elizabeth ArticlePageChunksGrid-kRgPDq DBpfE grid-layout--adrail narrow wide-adrail"><div class="GridItem-buSdEM PibmB grid--item grid-layout__content"><div class="BodyWrapper-ctnerm irSTVw body body__container article__body" data-journey-hook="client-content" data-testid="BodyWrapper"><div class="body__inner-container"><p class="has-dropcap has-dropcap__lead-standard-heading">Money, it‚Äôs often said, is a shared fiction. I give you a slip of paper or, more likely these days, a piece of plastic. You hand me eggs or butter or a White Chocolate Mocha Frappuccino, and we both walk away satisfied. With cryptocurrency, the arrangement is more like a shared metafiction, and the instability of the genre is, presumably, part of the thrill. Dogecoin, a cryptocurrency that was created as a spoof, has <a data-offer-url="https://www.reuters.com/technology/dogeday-hashtags-help-meme-based-cryptocurrency-dogecoin-hit-new-high-2021-04-20/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.reuters.com/technology/dogeday-hashtags-help-meme-based-cryptocurrency-dogecoin-hit-new-high-2021-04-20/"}" href="https://www.reuters.com/technology/dogeday-hashtags-help-meme-based-cryptocurrency-dogecoin-hit-new-high-2021-04-20/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">risen in value</a> by eight thousand per cent since January, owing to a combination of <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/news/our-columnists/the-gamestop-saga-is-dangerous-and-all-too-familiar">GameStop-style</a> pumping and boosterish tweets from Elon Musk. On Tuesday, which backers proclaimed DogeDay, the cryptocurrency  was valued at more than fifty billion dollars, which is more than the market cap of Ford. Coinbase, a cryptocurrency exchange, went public last Wednesday; almost immediately, it became worth more than G.M.</p><div class="GenericCalloutWrapper-XXWD kRETYb callout--has-top-border" data-testid="GenericCallout"><div class="ExternalLinkEmbedWrapper-fsNOnc koKdtk" data-testid="external-link-embed--inline"><div class="ExternalLinkEmbedText-cWlfxm koTmND"><a aria-label="<strong>More on the Environment</strong>" class="external-link external-link-embed__hed-link button" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.newyorker.com/newsletter/the-climate-crisis"}" href="https://www.newyorker.com/newsletter/the-climate-crisis" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank"><span class="BaseWrap-sc-TURhJ BaseText-fFzBQt ExternalLinkEmbedHed-gXJklG eTiIvU hGQOos jVlHJg"><strong>More on the Environment</strong></span></a><p class="BaseWrap-sc-TURhJ BaseText-fFzBQt ExternalLinkEmbedDek-MqhVd eTiIvU jBDyPt eiNCwc"><em>Sign up to receive news and commentary in our Climate Crisis newsletter.</em></p></div><a aria-label="<strong>More on the Environment</strong>" class="external-link external-link-embed__image-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.newyorker.com/newsletter/the-climate-crisis"}" href="https://www.newyorker.com/newsletter/the-climate-crisis" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank"><picture class="ResponsiveImagePicture-jIKgcS fArnhQ ExternalLinkEmbedResponsiveImage-hxycEw fBpxxG responsive-image"><img alt="" class="ResponsiveImageContainer-dlOMGF byslZC responsive-image__image" src="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5b8855b7b40a9d62f099c8a4/1:1/w_200%2Cc_limit/undefined" srcSet="https://media.newyorker.com/photos/5b8855b7b40a9d62f099c8a4/1:1/w_120,c_limit/undefined 120w" sizes="100vw"/></picture></a></div></div><p class="paywall">The mainstreaming of cryptocurrency, as it‚Äôs been called, is obviously a big deal for the world of finance. It‚Äôs also a big deal for the world of, well, the world. This is particularly true in the case of the ur-cryptocurrency, Bitcoin. Like Dogecoin, bitcoin has recently surged in value. In April, 2020, a coin was worth about seven thousand dollars; today, it‚Äôs worth more than fifty-five thousand. (It hit a record high of $64,895.22 on April 14th, but has since fallen off.) As the cost of investing in bitcoin has soared, so, too, has the potential profit in ‚Äúmining‚Äù it. Bitcoin mining is, of course, purely metaphorical, but the results can be every bit as destructive as with the real thing.</p><p class="paywall">According to the Cambridge Bitcoin Electricity Consumption Index, bitcoin-mining operations worldwide <a data-offer-url="https://cbeci.org/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://cbeci.org/"}" href="https://cbeci.org/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">now use energy</a> at the rate of nearly a hundred and twenty terawatt-hours per year. This is about the annual domestic electricity consumption of the entire nation of Sweden. According to the Web site Digiconomist, a single bitcoin transaction uses <a data-offer-url="https://digiconomist.net/bitcoin-energy-consumption" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://digiconomist.net/bitcoin-energy-consumption"}" href="https://digiconomist.net/bitcoin-energy-consumption" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">the same amount of power</a> that the average American household consumes in a month, and is responsible for roughly a million times more carbon emissions than a single Visa transaction. At a time when the world desperately needs to cut carbon emissions, does it make sense to be devoting a Sweden‚Äôs worth of electricity to a virtual currency? The answer would seem, pretty clearly, to be no. And, yet, here we are.</p><p class="has-dropcap has-dropcap__lead-standard-heading paywall">The Greenidge Generating Station in Dresden, New York, sits on the shores of Seneca Lake, about an hour southeast of Rochester. It was originally built in the nineteen-thirties to run on coal; over the decades, new units were added and older ones shuttered. The power station ceased operations in 2011, and it sat idle until it was purchased by a private-equity firm and converted to run on natural gas. In 2017, under the ownership of Greenidge Generation Holdings, the plant reportedly began operating as a ‚Äúpeaker plant,‚Äù to provide power to the grid during times of high demand. (A spokesperson noted that the plant ‚Äúis permitted to run 24/7.‚Äù) Then, in 2019, it was announced that the plant would  power bitcoin mining.</p><p class="paywall">Mining is the process by which bitcoin is both created and accounted for. Instead of being cleared by, say, a bank, bitcoin transactions are recorded by a decentralized network‚Äîa blockchain. Miners compete to register the latest ‚Äúblock‚Äù of transactions by solving cryptographic puzzles. The first one to the solution is rewarded with freshly minted bitcoin. Miners today receive 6.25 bitcoins per block, which, at current values, are worth more than three hundred thousand dollars.</p><p class="paywall">It‚Äôs unclear exactly who dreamt up bitcoin, so no one knows what this person (or persons) was thinking when the mining protocols were first established. But, as Ari Juels, a computer scientist at Cornell Tech, recently explained to me, the arrangement seems to have been designed with equity in mind. Anyone devoting a processor to the enterprise would have just as much stake in the outcome as anyone else. As is so often the case, though, the ideal was soon subverted.</p><p class="paywall">‚ÄúWhat was quickly discovered is that specialized computing devices‚Äîso-called mining rigs‚Äîare much, much more effective at solving these puzzles,‚Äù Juels said. ‚ÄúAnd, in addition, there are economies of scale in the operation of these mining groups. So the process of mining, which was originally conducted by a loose federation of presumably individual participants with ordinary computing devices, has now become heavily consolidated.‚Äù</p><div class="Container-imGeBO ftlPuP"></div><p class="paywall">Because rig ‚Äúfarms,‚Äù which are essentially like server farms, consume a lot of energy, bitcoin-mining operations tend to chase cheap electricity. Roughly seventy per cent of bitcoin mining today takes place in China. (<a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-021-22256-3">A recent study</a> found that the associated electricity consumption could ‚Äúpotentially undermine‚Äù China‚Äôs efforts to curb its carbon emissions.) Russia is also a bitcoin-mining center‚Äîthere are big operations in Siberia, where cold temperatures help keep rig farms from overheating‚Äîas is Iran, where electricity is subsidized.</p><div data-attr-viewport-monitor="inline-recirc" class="inline-recirc-wrapper inline-recirc-observer-target-1 viewport-monitor-anchor"></div><p class="paywall">In the United States, home to about seven per cent of the world‚Äôs bitcoin mining, finding cheap power can be complicated. A few years ago, miners ‚Äú<a data-offer-url="https://www.forbes.com/sites/danieldambrosio/2018/10/31/plattsburgh-turns-back-invasion-of-bitcoin-miners" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.forbes.com/sites/danieldambrosio/2018/10/31/plattsburgh-turns-back-invasion-of-bitcoin-miners"}" href="https://www.forbes.com/sites/danieldambrosio/2018/10/31/plattsburgh-turns-back-invasion-of-bitcoin-miners" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">descended upon</a>‚Äù the city of Plattsburgh, New York, about a hundred and fifty miles north of Albany, which gets much of its electricity from hydroelectric dams on the St.¬†Lawrence River. The power is relatively inexpensive, but, once Plattsburgh uses up its allotment, it has to purchase more at higher rates. Bitcoin mining drove up the cost of electricity in the city so dramatically that, in 2018, Plattsburgh enacted a moratorium on new mining operations.</p><p class="paywall">Buying a generating station, as Greenidge Generation Holdings has done, is a way around the problem. Let others pay retail; Greenidge now gets its power ‚Äúbehind the meter.‚Äù The firm <a data-offer-url="https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20210322005353/en/Bitcoin-Miner-Greenidge-Generation-Holdings-Inc.-and-Support.com-Inc.-Nasdaq-SPRT-Announce-Merger-Agreement" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20210322005353/en/Bitcoin-Miner-Greenidge-Generation-Holdings-Inc.-and-Support.com-Inc.-Nasdaq-SPRT-Announce-Merger-Agreement"}" href="https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20210322005353/en/Bitcoin-Miner-Greenidge-Generation-Holdings-Inc.-and-Support.com-Inc.-Nasdaq-SPRT-Announce-Merger-Agreement" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">recently announced</a> that it was going public, via a merger with a Nasdaq-listed company called Support.com, and boasted that it ‚Äúexpects to be the first publicly traded bitcoin mining company with a wholly-owned power plant.‚Äù In the announcement, Greenidge said that it was planning to more than double its bitcoin-mining operations in Dresden by the fall of 2021, and to double them again by the end of 2022. It further declared that it intends to ‚Äúreplicate its vertically integrated mining model at other power sites.‚Äù</p><p class="paywall">To expand its operations in Dresden, Greenidge will have to burn more and more natural gas, thus producing correspondingly more greenhouse-gas emissions. The firm‚Äôs plans have sparked demonstrations in the Finger Lakes region. On Saturday, a hundred protesters marched to the gates of the plant.</p><p class="paywall">‚ÄúThis is a test case,‚Äù Joseph Campbell, the president of Seneca Lake Guardian, the group that organized the march, <a data-offer-url="https://www.wrfi.org/2021/04/19/environmentalists-rally-against-greenidge-expansion-state-lawmakers-take-notice/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://www.wrfi.org/2021/04/19/environmentalists-rally-against-greenidge-expansion-state-lawmakers-take-notice/"}" href="https://www.wrfi.org/2021/04/19/environmentalists-rally-against-greenidge-expansion-state-lawmakers-take-notice/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">told WRFI</a>, an Ithaca radio station. Two days later, the local planning board approved Greenidge‚Äôs application to build four new structures at the site, to house more mining rigs. Members of the planning board said that for, legal reasons, they were barred from considering the broader implications of their decision. ‚ÄúWe know that bitcoin is a big waste of energy,‚Äù the chairman of the planning board, David Granzin, <a data-offer-url="https://wskg.org/news/torrey-planning-board-approves-greenidge-bitcoin-mining-plan/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://wskg.org/news/torrey-planning-board-approves-greenidge-bitcoin-mining-plan/"}" href="https://wskg.org/news/torrey-planning-board-approves-greenidge-bitcoin-mining-plan/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">said</a>. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre bound by law.‚Äù</p><p class="paywall">Whether this is, in fact, the case is debatable. What‚Äôs beyond debate‚Äîor should be, at least‚Äîis that this is a matter that shouldn‚Äôt be left to a local planning board to decide. There‚Äôs no way for New York, or the U.S. as a whole, to meet its emissions-reductions goals if old generating stations, rather than being closed, are converted into bitcoin-mining operations. Greenidge may become the first mining firm with a ‚Äúwholly-owned power plant,‚Äù but, unless the state or federal government steps in, it won‚Äôt be the last: another cryptocurrency firm, Digihost International, <a data-offer-url="https://fingerlakes1.com/2021/04/19/bitcoin-miners-scout-for-site-in-watkins-glen-canadian-bitcoin-miner-buys-power-plant-near-buffalo/" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://fingerlakes1.com/2021/04/19/bitcoin-miners-scout-for-site-in-watkins-glen-canadian-bitcoin-miner-buys-power-plant-near-buffalo/"}" href="https://fingerlakes1.com/2021/04/19/bitcoin-miners-scout-for-site-in-watkins-glen-canadian-bitcoin-miner-buys-power-plant-near-buffalo/" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">has already applied</a> to New York State‚Äôs Public Service Commission for permission to purchase a natural-gas-burning station near Buffalo. As representatives of Earthjustice and the Sierra Club recently <a data-offer-url="https://waterfrontonline.files.wordpress.com/2021/04/earthjusticeletterapr6.pdf" class="external-link" data-event-click="{"element":"ExternalLink","outgoingURL":"https://waterfrontonline.files.wordpress.com/2021/04/earthjusticeletterapr6.pdf"}" href="https://waterfrontonline.files.wordpress.com/2021/04/earthjusticeletterapr6.pdf" rel="nofollow noopener" target="_blank">put it</a>,  in a letter to officials of New York‚Äôs Department of Environmental Conservation, ‚Äúadditional scrutiny¬†.¬†.¬†. is essential to prevent the floodgates opening for other retiring power plants.‚Äù</p><p class="paywall">Andrew Yang, the former Presidential candidate who‚Äôs now running for mayor of New York City, has said that he wants to turn the city into a cryptocurrency-mining hub. It‚Äôs hard to imagine a worse idea. The city is already looking at spending billions of dollars to protect itself from sea-level rise; increased emissions are pretty much the last thing it needs. Forward-looking politicians should be thinking about ways not to buoy bitcoin mining but to bury it.</p></div></div></div><div class="GridItem-buSdEM gKfJBS grid--item grid-layout__aside"><aside power‚Äîand can be as destructive as the real thing.","head.social.opinion":"false","head.jsonld":[{"@context":"http:\u002F\u002Fschema.org","@type":"NewsArticle","articleBody":"+++dropcap\n\nMoney, it‚Äôs often said, is a shared fiction. I give you a slip of paper or, more likely these days, a piece of plastic. You hand me eggs or butter or a White Chocolate Mocha Frappuccino, and we both walk away satisfied. With cryptocurrency, the arrangement is more like a shared metafiction, and the instability of the genre is, presumably, part of the thrill. Dogecoin, a cryptocurrency that was created as a spoof, has [risen in value](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.reuters.com\u002Ftechnology\u002Fdogeday-hashtags-help-meme-based-cryptocurrency-dogecoin-hit-new-high-2021-04-20\u002F) by eight thousand per cent since January, owing to a combination of [GameStop-style](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Four-columnists\u002Fthe-gamestop-saga-is-dangerous-and-all-too-familiar) pumping and boosterish tweets from Elon Musk. On Tuesday, which backers proclaimed DogeDay, the cryptocurrency  was valued at more than fifty billion dollars, which is more than the market cap of Ford. Coinbase, a cryptocurrency exchange, went public last Wednesday; almost immediately, it became worth more than G.M.\n\n+++\n\n+++inset-right\n\n[#externallink: \u002Fexternallinks\u002F6081cecb3629e8f5c79f662d]\n\n+++\n\nThe mainstreaming of cryptocurrency, as it‚Äôs been called, is obviously a big deal for the world of finance. It‚Äôs also a big deal for the world of, well, the world. This is particularly true in the case of the ur-cryptocurrency, Bitcoin. Like Dogecoin, bitcoin has recently surged in value. In April, 2020, a coin was worth about seven thousand dollars; today, it‚Äôs worth more than fifty-five thousand. (It hit a record high of $64,895.22 on April 14th, but has since fallen off.) As the cost of investing in bitcoin has soared, so, too, has the potential profit in ‚Äúmining‚Äù it. Bitcoin mining is, of course, purely metaphorical, but the results can be every bit as destructive as with the real thing.\n\nAccording to the Cambridge Bitcoin Electricity Consumption Index, bitcoin-mining operations worldwide [now use energy](https:\u002F\u002Fcbeci.org\u002F) at the rate of nearly a hundred and twenty terawatt-hours per year. This is about the annual domestic electricity consumption of the entire nation of Sweden. According to the Web site Digiconomist, a single bitcoin transaction uses [the same amount of power](https:\u002F\u002Fdigiconomist.net\u002Fbitcoin-energy-consumption) that the average American household consumes in a month, and is responsible for roughly a million times more carbon emissions than a single Visa transaction. At a time when the world desperately needs to cut carbon emissions, does it make sense to be devoting a Sweden‚Äôs worth of electricity to a virtual currency? The answer would seem, pretty clearly, to be no. And, yet, here we are.\n\n+++dropcap\n\nThe Greenidge Generating Station in Dresden, New York, sits on the shores of Seneca Lake, about an hour southeast of Rochester. It was originally built in the nineteen-thirties to run on coal; over the decades, new units were added and older ones shuttered. The power station ceased operations in 2011, and it sat idle until it was purchased by a private-equity firm and converted to run on natural gas. In 2017, under the ownership of Greenidge Generation Holdings, the plant reportedly began operating as a ‚Äúpeaker plant,‚Äù to provide power to the grid during times of high demand. (A spokesperson noted that the plant ‚Äúis permitted to run 24\u002F7.‚Äù) Then, in 2019, it was announced that the plant would  power bitcoin mining.\n\n+++\n\nMining is the process by which bitcoin is both created and accounted for. Instead of being cleared by, say, a bank, bitcoin transactions are recorded by a decentralized network‚Äîa blockchain. Miners compete to register the latest ‚Äúblock‚Äù of transactions by solving cryptographic puzzles. The first one to the solution is rewarded with freshly minted bitcoin. Miners today receive 6.25 bitcoins per block, which, at current values, are worth more than three hundred thousand dollars.\n\nIt‚Äôs unclear exactly who dreamt up bitcoin, so no one knows what this person (or persons) was thinking when the mining protocols were first established. But, as Ari Juels, a computer scientist at Cornell Tech, recently explained to me, the arrangement seems to have been designed with equity in mind. Anyone devoting a processor to the enterprise would have just as much stake in the outcome as anyone else. As is so often the case, though, the ideal was soon subverted.\n\n‚ÄúWhat was quickly discovered is that specialized computing devices‚Äîso-called mining rigs‚Äîare much, much more effective at solving these puzzles,‚Äù Juels said. ‚ÄúAnd, in addition, there are economies of scale in the operation of these mining groups. So the process of mining, which was originally conducted by a loose federation of presumably individual participants with ordinary computing devices, has now become heavily consolidated.‚Äù\n\nBecause rig ‚Äúfarms,‚Äù which are essentially like server farms, consume a lot of energy, bitcoin-mining operations tend to chase cheap electricity. Roughly seventy per cent of bitcoin mining today takes place in China. ([A recent study](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nature.com\u002Farticles\u002Fs41467-021-22256-3) found that the associated electricity consumption could ‚Äúpotentially undermine‚Äù China‚Äôs efforts to curb its carbon emissions.) Russia is also a bitcoin-mining center‚Äîthere are big operations in Siberia, where cold temperatures help keep rig farms from overheating‚Äîas is Iran, where electricity is subsidized.\n\nIn the United States, home to about seven per cent of the world‚Äôs bitcoin mining, finding cheap power can be complicated. A few years ago, miners ‚Äú[descended upon](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.forbes.com\u002Fsites\u002Fdanieldambrosio\u002F2018\u002F10\u002F31\u002Fplattsburgh-turns-back-invasion-of-bitcoin-miners)‚Äù the city of Plattsburgh, New York, about a hundred and fifty miles north of Albany, which gets much of its electricity from hydroelectric dams on the St. Lawrence River. The power is relatively inexpensive, but, once Plattsburgh uses up its allotment, it has to purchase more at higher rates. Bitcoin mining drove up the cost of electricity in the city so dramatically that, in 2018, Plattsburgh enacted a moratorium on new mining operations.\n\nBuying a generating station, as Greenidge Generation Holdings has done, is a way around the problem. Let others pay retail; Greenidge now gets its power ‚Äúbehind the meter.‚Äù The firm [recently announced](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.businesswire.com\u002Fnews\u002Fhome\u002F20210322005353\u002Fen\u002FBitcoin-Miner-Greenidge-Generation-Holdings-Inc.-and-Support.com-Inc.-Nasdaq-SPRT-Announce-Merger-Agreement) that it was going public, via a merger with a Nasdaq-listed company called Support.com, and boasted that it ‚Äúexpects to be the first publicly traded bitcoin mining company with a wholly-owned power plant.‚Äù In the announcement, Greenidge said that it was planning to more than double its bitcoin-mining operations in Dresden by the fall of 2021, and to double them again by the end of 2022. It further declared that it intends to ‚Äúreplicate its vertically integrated mining model at other power sites.‚Äù\n\nTo expand its operations in Dresden, Greenidge will have to burn more and more natural gas, thus producing correspondingly more greenhouse-gas emissions. The firm‚Äôs plans have sparked demonstrations in the Finger Lakes region. On Saturday, a hundred protesters marched to the gates of the plant.\n\n‚ÄúThis is a test case,‚Äù Joseph Campbell, the president of Seneca Lake Guardian, the group that organized the march, [told WRFI](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.wrfi.org\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F19\u002Fenvironmentalists-rally-against-greenidge-expansion-state-lawmakers-take-notice\u002F), an Ithaca radio station. Two days later, the local planning board approved Greenidge‚Äôs application to build four new structures at the site, to house more mining rigs. Members of the planning board said that for, legal reasons, they were barred from considering the broader implications of their decision. ‚ÄúWe know that bitcoin is a big waste of energy,‚Äù the chairman of the planning board, David Granzin, [said](https:\u002F\u002Fwskg.org\u002Fnews\u002Ftorrey-planning-board-approves-greenidge-bitcoin-mining-plan\u002F). ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre bound by law.‚Äù\n\nWhether this is, in fact, the case is debatable. What‚Äôs beyond debate‚Äîor should be, at least‚Äîis that this is a matter that shouldn‚Äôt be left to a local planning board to decide. There‚Äôs no way for New York, or the U.S. as a whole, to meet its emissions-reductions goals if old generating stations, rather than being closed, are converted into bitcoin-mining operations. Greenidge may become the first mining firm with a ‚Äúwholly-owned power plant,‚Äù but, unless the state or federal government steps in, it won‚Äôt be the last: another cryptocurrency firm, Digihost International, [has already applied](https:\u002F\u002Ffingerlakes1.com\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F19\u002Fbitcoin-miners-scout-for-site-in-watkins-glen-canadian-bitcoin-miner-buys-power-plant-near-buffalo\u002F) to New York State‚Äôs Public Service Commission for permission to purchase a natural-gas-burning station near Buffalo. As representatives of Earthjustice and the Sierra Club recently [put it](https:\u002F\u002Fwaterfrontonline.files.wordpress.com\u002F2021\u002F04\u002Fearthjusticeletterapr6.pdf),  in a letter to officials of New York‚Äôs Department of Environmental Conservation, ‚Äúadditional scrutiny . . . is essential to prevent the floodgates opening for other retiring power plants.‚Äù\n\nAndrew Yang, the former Presidential candidate who‚Äôs now running for mayor of New York City, has said that he wants to turn the city into a cryptocurrency-mining hub. It‚Äôs hard to imagine a worse idea. The city is already looking at spending billions of dollars to protect itself from sea-level rise; increased emissions are pretty much the last thing it needs. Forward-looking politicians should be thinking about ways not to buoy bitcoin mining but to bury it.\n\n","articleSection":"daily comment","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Elizabeth readabilityObject.title: Why Bitcoin Is Bad for the Environment
readabilityObject.content:
Money, it‚Äôs often said, is a shared fiction. I give you a slip of paper or, more likely these days, a piece of plastic. You hand me eggs or butter or a White Chocolate Mocha Frappuccino, and we both walk away satisfied. With cryptocurrency, the arrangement is more like a shared metafiction, and the instability of the genre is, presumably, part of the thrill. Dogecoin, a cryptocurrency that was created as a spoof, has risen in value by eight thousand per cent since January, owing to a combination of GameStop-style pumping and boosterish tweets from Elon Musk. On Tuesday, which backers proclaimed DogeDay, the cryptocurrency was valued at more than fifty billion dollars, which is more than the market cap of Ford. Coinbase, a cryptocurrency exchange, went public last Wednesday; almost immediately, it became worth more than G.M.

The mainstreaming of cryptocurrency, as it‚Äôs been called, is obviously a big deal for the world of finance. It‚Äôs also a big deal for the world of, well, the world. This is particularly true in the case of the ur-cryptocurrency, Bitcoin. Like Dogecoin, bitcoin has recently surged in value. In April, 2020, a coin was worth about seven thousand dollars; today, it‚Äôs worth more than fifty-five thousand. (It hit a record high of $64,895.22 on April 14th, but has since fallen off.) As the cost of investing in bitcoin has soared, so, too, has the potential profit in ‚Äúmining‚Äù it. Bitcoin mining is, of course, purely metaphorical, but the results can be every bit as destructive as with the real thing.

According to the Cambridge Bitcoin Electricity Consumption Index, bitcoin-mining operations worldwide now use energy at the rate of nearly a hundred and twenty terawatt-hours per year. This is about the annual domestic electricity consumption of the entire nation of Sweden. According to the Web site Digiconomist, a single bitcoin transaction uses the same amount of power that the average American household consumes in a month, and is responsible for roughly a million times more carbon emissions than a single Visa transaction. At a time when the world desperately needs to cut carbon emissions, does it make sense to be devoting a Sweden‚Äôs worth of electricity to a virtual currency? The answer would seem, pretty clearly, to be no. And, yet, here we are.

The Greenidge Generating Station in Dresden, New York, sits on the shores of Seneca Lake, about an hour southeast of Rochester. It was originally built in the nineteen-thirties to run on coal; over the decades, new units were added and older ones shuttered. The power station ceased operations in 2011, and it sat idle until it was purchased by a private-equity firm and converted to run on natural gas. In 2017, under the ownership of Greenidge Generation Holdings, the plant reportedly began operating as a ‚Äúpeaker plant,‚Äù to provide power to the grid during times of high demand. (A spokesperson noted that the plant ‚Äúis permitted to run 24/7.‚Äù) Then, in 2019, it was announced that the plant would power bitcoin mining.

Mining is the process by which bitcoin is both created and accounted for. Instead of being cleared by, say, a bank, bitcoin transactions are recorded by a decentralized network‚Äîa blockchain. Miners compete to register the latest ‚Äúblock‚Äù of transactions by solving cryptographic puzzles. The first one to the solution is rewarded with freshly minted bitcoin. Miners today receive 6.25 bitcoins per block, which, at current values, are worth more than three hundred thousand dollars.

It‚Äôs unclear exactly who dreamt up bitcoin, so no one knows what this person (or persons) was thinking when the mining protocols were first established. But, as Ari Juels, a computer scientist at Cornell Tech, recently explained to me, the arrangement seems to have been designed with equity in mind. Anyone devoting a processor to the enterprise would have just as much stake in the outcome as anyone else. As is so often the case, though, the ideal was soon subverted.

‚ÄúWhat was quickly discovered is that specialized computing devices‚Äîso-called mining rigs‚Äîare much, much more effective at solving these puzzles,‚Äù Juels said. ‚ÄúAnd, in addition, there are economies of scale in the operation of these mining groups. So the process of mining, which was originally conducted by a loose federation of presumably individual participants with ordinary computing devices, has now become heavily consolidated.‚Äù

Because rig ‚Äúfarms,‚Äù which are essentially like server farms, consume a lot of energy, bitcoin-mining operations tend to chase cheap electricity. Roughly seventy per cent of bitcoin mining today takes place in China. (A recent study found that the associated electricity consumption could ‚Äúpotentially undermine‚Äù China‚Äôs efforts to curb its carbon emissions.) Russia is also a bitcoin-mining center‚Äîthere are big operations in Siberia, where cold temperatures help keep rig farms from overheating‚Äîas is Iran, where electricity is subsidized.

In the United States, home to about seven per cent of the world‚Äôs bitcoin mining, finding cheap power can be complicated. A few years ago, miners ‚Äúdescended upon‚Äù the city of Plattsburgh, New York, about a hundred and fifty miles north of Albany, which gets much of its electricity from hydroelectric dams on the St. Lawrence River. The power is relatively inexpensive, but, once Plattsburgh uses up its allotment, it has to purchase more at higher rates. Bitcoin mining drove up the cost of electricity in the city so dramatically that, in 2018, Plattsburgh enacted a moratorium on new mining operations.

Buying a generating station, as Greenidge Generation Holdings has done, is a way around the problem. Let others pay retail; Greenidge now gets its power ‚Äúbehind the meter.‚Äù The firm recently announced that it was going public, via a merger with a Nasdaq-listed company called Support.com, and boasted that it ‚Äúexpects to be the first publicly traded bitcoin mining company with a wholly-owned power plant.‚Äù In the announcement, Greenidge said that it was planning to more than double its bitcoin-mining operations in Dresden by the fall of 2021, and to double them again by the end of 2022. It further declared that it intends to ‚Äúreplicate its vertically integrated mining model at other power sites.‚Äù

To expand its operations in Dresden, Greenidge will have to burn more and more natural gas, thus producing correspondingly more greenhouse-gas emissions. The firm‚Äôs plans have sparked demonstrations in the Finger Lakes region. On Saturday, a hundred protesters marched to the gates of the plant.

‚ÄúThis is a test case,‚Äù Joseph Campbell, the president of Seneca Lake Guardian, the group that organized the march, told WRFI, an Ithaca radio station. Two days later, the local planning board approved Greenidge‚Äôs application to build four new structures at the site, to house more mining rigs. Members of the planning board said that for, legal reasons, they were barred from considering the broader implications of their decision. ‚ÄúWe know that bitcoin is a big waste of energy,‚Äù the chairman of the planning board, David Granzin, said. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre bound by law.‚Äù

Whether this is, in fact, the case is debatable. What‚Äôs beyond debate‚Äîor should be, at least‚Äîis that this is a matter that shouldn‚Äôt be left to a local planning board to decide. There‚Äôs no way for New York, or the U.S. as a whole, to meet its emissions-reductions goals if old generating stations, rather than being closed, are converted into bitcoin-mining operations. Greenidge may become the first mining firm with a ‚Äúwholly-owned power plant,‚Äù but, unless the state or federal government steps in, it won‚Äôt be the last: another cryptocurrency firm, Digihost International, has already applied to New York State‚Äôs Public Service Commission for permission to purchase a natural-gas-burning station near Buffalo. As representatives of Earthjustice and the Sierra Club recently put it, in a letter to officials of New York‚Äôs Department of Environmental Conservation, ‚Äúadditional scrutiny . . . is essential to prevent the floodgates opening for other retiring power plants.‚Äù

Andrew Yang, the former Presidential candidate who‚Äôs now running for mayor of New York City, has said that he wants to turn the city into a cryptocurrency-mining hub. It‚Äôs hard to imagine a worse idea. The city is already looking at spending billions of dollars to protect itself from sea-level rise; increased emissions are pretty much the last thing it needs. Forward-looking politicians should be thinking about ways not to buoy bitcoin mining but to bury it.

readabilityObject.excerpt: Elizabeth Kolbert writes about the excessive greenhouse-gas emissions produced by cryptocurrency-mining operations, and reports on old power plants in New York State that are being converted to provide electricity to mining farms in the region.

([A recent study](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-021-22256-3) found that the associated electricity consumption could ‚Äúpotentially undermine‚Äù China‚Äôs efforts to curb its carbon emissions.) Russia is also a bitcoin-mining center‚Äîthere are big operations in Siberia, where cold temperatures help keep rig farms from overheating‚Äîas is Iran, where electricity is subsidized.

In the United States, home to about seven per cent of the world‚Äôs bitcoin mining, finding cheap power can be complicated. A few years ago, miners ‚Äú[descended upon](https://www.forbes.com/sites/danieldambrosio/2018/10/31/plattsburgh-turns-back-invasion-of-bitcoin-miners)‚Äù the city of Plattsburgh, New York, about a hundred and fifty miles north of Albany, which gets much of its electricity from hydroelectric dams on the St. Lawrence River. The power is relatively inexpensive, but, once Plattsburgh uses up its allotment, it has to purchase more at higher rates. Bitcoin mining drove up the cost of electricity in the city so dramatically that, in 2018, Plattsburgh enacted a moratorium on new mining operations.

Buying a generating station, as Greenidge Generation Holdings has done, is a way around the problem. Let others pay retail; Greenidge now gets its power ‚Äúbehind the meter.‚Äù The firm [recently announced](https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20210322005353/en/Bitcoin-Miner-Greenidge-Generation-Holdings-Inc.-and-Support.com-Inc.-Nasdaq-SPRT-Announce-Merger-Agreement) that it was going public, via a merger with a Nasdaq-listed company called Support.com, and boasted that it ‚Äúexpects to be the first publicly traded bitcoin mining company with a wholly-owned power plant.‚Äù In the announcement, Greenidge said that it was planning to more than double its bitcoin-mining operations in Dresden by the fall of 2021, and to double them again by the end of 2022. It further declared that it intends to ‚Äúreplicate its vertically integrated mining model at other power sites.‚Äù

To expand its operations in Dresden, Greenidge will have to burn more and more natural gas, thus producing correspondingly more greenhouse-gas emissions. The firm‚Äôs plans have sparked demonstrations in the Finger Lakes region. On Saturday, a hundred protesters marched to the gates of the plant.

‚ÄúThis is a test case,‚Äù Joseph Campbell, the president of Seneca Lake Guardian, the group that organized the march, [told WRFI](https://www.wrfi.org/2021/04/19/environmentalists-rally-against-greenidge-expansion-state-lawmakers-take-notice/), an Ithaca radio station. Two days later, the local planning board approved Greenidge‚Äôs application to build four new structures at the site, to house more mining rigs. Members of the planning board said that for, legal reasons, they were barred from considering the broader implications of their decision. ‚ÄúWe know that bitcoin is a big waste of energy,‚Äù the chairman of the planning board, David Granzin, [said](https://wskg.org/news/torrey-planning-board-approves-greenidge-bitcoin-mining-plan/). ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre bound by law.‚Äù

Whether this is, in fact, the case is debatable. What‚Äôs beyond debate‚Äîor should be, at least‚Äîis that this is a matter that shouldn‚Äôt be left to a local planning board to decide. There‚Äôs no way for New York, or the U.S. as a whole, to meet its emissions-reductions goals if old generating stations, rather than being closed, are converted into bitcoin-mining operations. Greenidge may become the first mining firm with a ‚Äúwholly-owned power plant,‚Äù but, unless the state or federal government steps in, it won‚Äôt be the last: another cryptocurrency firm, Digihost International, [has already applied](https://fingerlakes1.com/2021/04/19/bitcoin-miners-scout-for-site-in-watkins-glen-canadian-bitcoin-miner-buys-power-plant-near-buffalo/) to New York State‚Äôs Public Service Commission for permission to purchase a natural-gas-burning station near Buffalo. As representatives of Earthjustice and the Sierra Club recently [put it](https://waterfrontonline.files.wordpress.com/2021/04/earthjusticeletterapr6.pdf),  in a letter to officials of New York‚Äôs Department of Environmental Conservation, ‚Äúadditional scrutiny . . . is essential to prevent the floodgates opening for other retiring power plants.‚Äù

Andrew Yang, the former Presidential candidate who‚Äôs now running for mayor of New York City, has said that he wants to turn the city into a cryptocurrency-mining hub. It‚Äôs hard to imagine a worse idea. The city is already looking at spending billions of dollars to protect itself from sea-level rise; increased emissions are pretty much the last thing it needs. Forward-looking politicians should be thinking about ways not to buoy bitcoin mining but to bury it.
jsonLd.alternativeHeadline: Elizabeth Kolbert writes about the excessive greenhouse-gas emissions produced by cryptocurrency-mining operations, and reports on old power plants in New York State that are being converted to provide electricity to mining farms in the region.
